open_questions.title: Docker
open_questions.description: What is Docker?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is Docker?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Docker is a platform for developing, shipping, and running applications inside containers. Containers allow a developer to package up an application with all of the parts it needs, such as libraries and other dependencies, and ship it all out as one package. This ensures that the application will run on any other Linux machine regardless of any customized settings that machine might have that could differ from the machine used for writing and testing the code.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Containerization
open_questions.description: What is containerization?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is containerization?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Containerization is a technology that encapsulates an application and its dependencies into a 'container'. This allows the application to run consistently across different computing environments.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A container
open_questions.description: What is a container?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a container?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A container is a lightweight, standalone executable package that includes everything needed to run a piece of software: code, runtime, system tools, libraries, and settings. Containers ensure consistency across multiple environments, from development to testing and production, by encapsulating an application and its dependencies into a single, portable unit.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A hypervisor
open_questions.description: What is a hypervisor?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a hypervisor?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A hypervisor is software that creates and runs virtual machines (VMs). It allows multiple VMs, each with their own operating system, to share a single physical host's hardware resources. There are two types: Type 1 (bare-metal): runs directly on the host's hardware. Type 2 (hosted): runs on a conventional operating system. Hypervisors are essential in virtualization, enabling efficient resource utilization and isolation between different VMs.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The differences between containerization and virtualization.
open_questions.description: Explain the differences between containerization and virtualization.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the differences between containerization and virtualization.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Containerization involves packaging applications with their dependencies in containers, sharing the host's OS kernel. It's lightweight, offers quick startup, and efficient resource use. Ideal for consistent deployment environments. Virtualization creates full virtual machines with separate OS instances on a hypervisor. It's resource-intensive but provides stronger isolation and security. Suitable for running different OSs and applications needing full isolation.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The main components of Docker architecture.
open_questions.description: Explain the main components of Docker architecture.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the main components of Docker architecture.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Docker Daemon: The background service running on the host that manages building, running, and distributing Docker containers. Docker Client: The command-line interface that allows users to interact with the Docker Daemon. Docker Images: Read-only templates used to build containers. Docker Containers: Runnable instances of Docker images. Docker Registries: Storage and distribution systems for Docker images, with Docker Hub being the most common public registry.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Name some advantages of using Docker.
open_questions.description: Name some advantages of using Docker.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Name some advantages of using Docker.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Portability: Containers run consistently across different environments. Efficiency: Lightweight compared to virtual machines, saving system resources. Isolation: Containers are isolated, reducing conflicts between applications. Scalability: Easy to scale and distribute containerized applications. Rapid Deployment: Quick to build and deploy applications. Version Control and Reusability: Facilitates version control and reuse of container images. Simplified Configuration: Simplifies the setup and configuration of applications.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Name some disadvantages of using Docker.
open_questions.description: Name some disadvantages of using Docker.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Name some disadvantages of using Docker.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Security Concerns: Containers share the host OS kernel, potentially leading to security vulnerabilities. Complexity: Managing and orchestrating numerous containers can be complex. Persistent Storage: Managing data persistence for containers can be challenging. Performance Overhead: Some performance overhead, especially in high-density environments. Compatibility: Not all applications are suitable for containerization. Learning Curve: Requires learning new tools and concepts.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A Docker container’s lifecycle.
open_questions.description: Describe a Docker container’s lifecycle.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Describe a Docker container’s lifecycle.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Creation: A container is created from an image using docker create or docker run. Running: It enters a running state with docker start or during creation with docker run. Pausing: Containers can be paused and unpaused, freezing and unfreezing processes. Stopping: The container is stopped using docker stop, which sends a stop signal followed by a kill signal if the container doesn't stop gracefully. Restarting: A stopped container can be restarted with docker restart. Deletion: The container is removed from the system with docker rm.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Name the essential Docker commands and
open_questions.description: Name the essential Docker commands and what they do.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Name the essential Docker commands and what they do.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: docker run: Creates and starts a container from an image. docker build: Builds an image from a Dockerfile. docker pull: Pulls an image from a registry. docker push: Pushes an image to a registry. docker images: Lists all local images. docker ps: Lists running containers (add -a to include stopped containers). docker stop: Stops a running container. docker start: Starts a stopped container. docker rm: Removes one or more containers. docker rmi: Removes one or more images. docker exec: Executes a command in a running container. docker logs: Fetches logs of a container. docker compose: Manages multi-container applications.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: A Dockerfile is a text file that contains instructions for building a Docker image. It specifies the base image, dependencies, environment settings, and commands to run. Docker images are created from Dockerfiles using the docker build command.

open_questions.title: The difference between a Docker image
open_questions.description: Explain the difference between a Docker image and a Docker container.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the difference between a Docker image and a Docker container.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A Docker image is a lightweight, standalone, and executable package that includes everything needed to run a piece of software, including the code, runtime, libraries, environment variables, and config files. It's a read-only template. A Docker container is a runnable instance of a Docker image. When an image is run, it exists in memory and has a writable layer over the image for storing application state. Containers are isolated environments, but share the OS kernel and, where appropriate, binaries and libraries.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of Docker Compose
open_questions.description: What is the purpose of Docker Compose?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the purpose of Docker Compose?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Docker Compose is a tool for defining and running multi-container Docker applications. It uses a YAML file (docker-compose.yml) to configure the application's services, allowing you to orchestrate and manage multiple containers as a single service. This simplifies the process of deploying complex applications that require multiple interconnected containers.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Docker volumes
open_questions.description: What are Docker volumes?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are Docker volumes?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Docker volumes are storage areas attached to containers, used for managing persistent data. They are important because: Data Persistence: Data in volumes survives container restarts and removals, ensuring data isn't lost. Data Sharing: Volumes can be shared and reused among multiple containers. Independent Lifecycle: Volumes have a lifecycle independent of the container, allowing data to persist beyond the life of a container.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Container orchestration is the automated management of containerized applications, including deployment, scaling, load balancing, and self-healing. It is essential in modern application deployment to ensure high availability, scalability, and efficient resource utilization in dynamic container environments.

Give a small example

referenceAnswers.text: Docker Swarm is a container orchestration tool built into Docker. It allows you to manage a cluster of Docker hosts as a single virtual system, automating the deployment, scaling, and networking of containers. Swarm is designed for easy setup and integrates seamlessly with Docker's ecosystem.

open_questions.title: The difference between Docker and Kubernetes.
open_questions.description: Explain the difference between Docker and Kubernetes.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the difference between Docker and Kubernetes.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Docker is a platform for developing, shipping, and running applications in containers. It focuses on containerization and the efficient creation and deployment of containers. Kubernetes, is an orchestration system for managing containerized applications across a cluster of nodes. It handles scaling, load balancing, and deployment patterns of containers, typically those created by Docker. The key difference is that Docker is about creating and managing individual containers, while Kubernetes is about managing groups of containers at scale.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: You ensure security in Docker containers
open_questions.description: How do you ensure security in Docker containers?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "How do you ensure security in Docker containers?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: To ensure security in Docker containers: Use official or verified images from trusted registries. Keep images and containers updated with security patches. Configure least privilege user access to containers. Implement network segmentation and firewall rules. Regularly scan containers and images for vulnerabilities. Avoid storing sensitive data in containers. Use security tools and best practices for container orchestration.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of Docker image layers.
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of Docker image layers. How do they impact image size and build efficiency?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of Docker image layers. How do they impact image size and build efficiency?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Docker images are composed of multiple layers, each representing a set of changes to the image. Layers are cached and shared among images, which makes builds more efficient. When a change is made in a layer, only that layer and subsequent layers need to be rebuilt. This helps reduce image size and speeds up image builds.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of Docker health checks

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Docker health checks are used to determine the health status of a containerized application. They help in monitoring container health and automatically restarting containers that are in an unhealthy state. Health checks can be configured in a Dockerfile using the HEALTHCHECK instruction and specifying a command or script that determines container health.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Name some best practices when creating
open_questions.description: Name some best practices when creating a Dockerfile.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Name some best practices when creating a Dockerfile.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Use Official Base Images: Start with official, verified base images from Docker Hub. Minimize Layers: Combine related commands into single layers to reduce the image size. Use Multi-Stage Builds: Separate the build environment from the runtime environment to minimize the final image size. Specify Versions: Pin versions of base images and packages to ensure consistency and prevent unexpected changes. Leverage Build Cache: Order Dockerfile instructions to maximize layer caching for faster builds. Avoid Storing Sensitive Data: Don't include sensitive data or credentials directly in the Dockerfile or image. Optimize for Readability and Maintenance: Write clear, commented Dockerfiles for easier maintenance and understanding. Use .dockerignore: Exclude unnecessary files and directories to minimize the build context.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Can you provide an example of
open_questions.description: Can you provide an example of a docker-compose.yml file?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Can you provide an example of a docker-compose.yml file?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: yaml version: '3' services: web: image: nginx:latest ports: - "80:80" db: image: postgres:latest environment: POSTGRES_PASSWORD: example This file defines two services: web, using the latest Nginx image, and db, using the latest Postgres image. The Nginx service exposes port 80, and the Postgres service sets a default password.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The key concepts of Docker Swarm
open_questions.description: Explain the key concepts of Docker Swarm mode.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the key concepts of Docker Swarm mode.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Docker Swarm is a native clustering and orchestration tool for Docker. Key concepts include: Nodes: Individual machines (physical or virtual) that join the swarm, categorized as "managers" (orchestrate and manage the swarm) or "workers" (run swarm services). Services and Tasks: A service defines the desired state of container instances in the swarm. Each instance, or task, is a single container. Load Balancing: Swarm automatically balances service tasks across nodes for optimal resource utilization. Scaling: Services can be scaled up or down to adjust the number of replicas of a given task. Rolling Updates: Swarm supports rolling updates to services, allowing for zero-downtime deployments. Networking: Swarm provides networking features to connect services within the swarm securely.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Docker secrets and how can you
open_questions.description: What are Docker secrets and how can you use them?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are Docker secrets and how can you use them?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Docker secrets are used to securely manage sensitive data like passwords or API keys in containers. They enhance security by preventing exposure of sensitive data. You can use Docker secrets in a service by creating secrets and referencing them in the docker-compose.yml or Docker Swarm service configuration. Example: yaml // docker-compose.yaml version: '3.1' services: db: image: mysql:latest environment: MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD_FILE: /run/secrets/db_password secrets: - db_password secrets: db_password: file: ./db_password.txt
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of the EXPOSE instruction
open_questions.description: What is the purpose of the EXPOSE instruction in a Dockerfile, and how is it different from port mapping (using -p) when running containers?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the purpose of the EXPOSE instruction in a Dockerfile, and how is it different from port mapping (using -p) when running containers?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The EXPOSE instruction in a Dockerfile documents the ports that a container application listens on. It doesn't actually publish the ports to the host. Port mapping (-p option) is used at runtime to map container ports to host ports, allowing external access to the container's services.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Docker Desktop, and how does it
open_questions.description: What is Docker Desktop, and how does it differ from Docker Engine?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is Docker Desktop, and how does it differ from Docker Engine?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Docker Desktop is an application for MacOS and Windows that includes Docker Engine, a user-friendly interface, and additional features like Kubernetes integration and GUI-based management tools. Docker Engine is the core part of Docker, the runtime that builds and runs containers. The key difference is that Docker Desktop offers an integrated, easy-to-use environment with additional tools, while Docker Engine is the underlying technology that runs the containers.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Docker's concept of a Dockerfile context.
open_questions.description: Explain Docker's concept of a Dockerfile context.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain Docker's concept of a Dockerfile context.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The Dockerfile context is the set of files and directories that are sent to the Docker daemon during image building. It includes the Dockerfile itself and all files specified in COPY or ADD instructions. Managing it efficiently is important because a large context can slow down image builds and result in larger image sizes.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between Docker's CMD and
open_questions.description: Explain the difference between Docker's CMD and ENTRYPOINT instructions in a Dockerfile.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the difference between Docker's CMD and ENTRYPOINT instructions in a Dockerfile.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In a Dockerfile, CMD and ENTRYPOINT both specify commands to be executed when a Docker container starts, but they serve different purposes: CMD: Sets default command and/or parameters, which can be overwritten from the command line when the container is run. ENTRYPOINT: Configures a container with a command that does not get overwritten unless you explicitly use the --entrypoint flag. Parameters passed to docker run append to the ENTRYPOINT.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Docker's "attach" mode allows you to interact with the input and output of a running container. You can use the docker attach command followed by the container's name or ID to attach to a running container. This allows you to view its standard input, output, and error streams and interact with the container's console.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

Logging drivers: To configure log output to various destinations, such as files or remote services.

open_questions.title: Docker image layer caching
open_questions.description: What is Docker image layer caching?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is Docker image layer caching?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Docker image layer caching is a mechanism that allows Docker to reuse cached layers during image builds to improve efficiency. By ordering instructions in your Dockerfile efficiently and placing frequently changing instructions toward the end, you can take advantage of caching and avoid unnecessary rebuilds, thus speeding up image builds.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Docker image version pinning involves specifying a specific image tag (e.g., myapp:v1.0) in your deployment configuration. It is important in a production environment to ensure consistent and predictable deployments. By pinning to a specific version, you avoid unintentional updates and ensure that containers always use the same image version.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: How Docker networking works.
open_questions.description: Explain how Docker networking works.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain how Docker networking works.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Docker networking enables containers to communicate with each other and the external world. It uses network drivers to manage networking: Bridge Network: Default network for containers, allowing communication among them on the same host. Host Network: Containers use the host's network directly, facilitating external communication. Overlay Network: Enables communication among containers across different hosts, used in Docker Swarm. Custom Networks: Users can create custom networks for specific requirements. Containers communicate internally through these networks and externally via mapped ports on the host machine.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Can you describe the difference between
open_questions.description: Can you describe the difference between bridge and overlay networks?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Can you describe the difference between bridge and overlay networks?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In Docker, bridge and overlay networks are different types of network drivers: Bridge Network: The default network driver for Docker. It creates a private internal network for containers on the same Docker host, allowing them to communicate with each other. External access is managed through port mapping. Overlay Network: Used in multi-host Docker Swarm environments. It allows containers running on different Docker hosts to communicate with each other as if they were on the same host, facilitating communication across a cluster of Docker nodes.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Docker's copy-on-write (CoW) file system.
open_questions.description: Explain Docker's copy-on-write (CoW) file system.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain Docker's copy-on-write (CoW) file system.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Docker's copy-on-write (CoW) file system is a strategy where Docker containers share the same image layers until a container modifies them. When a file or directory from an image layer is changed, it's copied (written) to the container's writable layer, leaving the original image layer unchanged. This approach optimizes storage space and resource usage, as multiple containers can share the same base image without duplicating data, only diverging when changes occur.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The purpose of Dockerfile multistage builds.
open_questions.description: Explain the purpose of Dockerfile multistage builds.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the purpose of Dockerfile multistage builds.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Dockerfile multistage builds allow building lighter, more efficient Docker images by using multiple stages in a single Dockerfile. Each stage can use a different base image and include only the files necessary for that stage. The final stage can copy artifacts from previous stages, discarding everything else. This results in smaller final images by reducing layers and minimizing the footprint of runtime images, especially useful for compiled languages or when separating build-time dependencies from runtime dependencies.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: You ensure high availability in a
open_questions.description: How do you ensure high availability in a Docker Swarm cluster?

Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: To ensure high availability in a Docker Swarm cluster: Replicate Services: Run multiple replicas of services across different nodes. Use Multiple Manager Nodes: Have multiple manager nodes for fault tolerance. Distribute Nodes Geographically: Spread nodes across different physical locations. Regularly Update and Backup: Keep the system updated and back up Swarm's state. Monitor Health: Implement health checks and monitoring for automatic handling of failed containers or nodes.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The advantages of using Docker containers
open_questions.description: What are the advantages of using Docker containers in a microservices architecture?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the advantages of using Docker containers in a microservices architecture?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Isolation: Each microservice runs in a separate container, ensuring isolated environments. Scalability: Containers can be quickly started, stopped, and replicated, aiding in easy scaling of services. Consistency: Containers provide consistent environments across different stages of development, testing, and production. Efficiency: Containers are lightweight, use resources efficiently, and reduce overhead compared to virtual machines. Portability: Containers can run on any system that supports Docker, simplifying deployment across different platforms. Rapid Deployment: Faster deployment and restart times enhance development and operational agility.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: You monitor Docker containers and troubleshoot

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: To monitor Docker containers and troubleshoot issues, you can: Use the docker stats command for real-time container performance metrics. Implement logging drivers to capture container logs for analysis. Utilize Docker's built-in health checks to monitor container status. Employ external monitoring tools like Prometheus or cAdvisor for more comprehensive insights. Debug issues using the docker logs command to access container logs.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A Docker Namespace
open_questions.description: What is a Docker Namespace?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a Docker Namespace?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A Docker Namespace is a feature that provides isolation for Docker containers. It allows each container to have a separate view of the operating system, including its processes, network interfaces, users, and file systems. Namespaces ensure that activities in one container do not affect other containers or the host system, thereby enhancing security and stability.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between docker volumes and
open_questions.description: What is the difference between docker volumes and bind mounts?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between docker volumes and bind mounts?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Docker volumes are managed by Docker and are stored in a part of the host filesystem managed by Docker (/var/lib/docker/volumes/ by default). They're completely managed and isolated from the host filesystem. Bind mounts, on the other hand, can be stored anywhere on the host system. They might be used for sensitive files like system libraries or configuration files. They directly reflect the filesystem of the host, meaning changes to a bind mount are immediately reflected on the host, and vice versa.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice
